trans-unit.source: Use the following information if you are responsible for the Microsoft Rights Management sharing application on an enterprise network, or if you want more technical information than is in the <link><linkText>Rights Management sharing application user guide</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>FAQ for Microsoft Rights Management Sharing Application for Windows</linkText><title></title></link>:
trans-unit.target: Use the following information if you are responsible for the Microsoft Rights Management sharing application on an enterprise network, or if you want more technical information than is in the <link><linkText>Rights Management sharing application user guide</linkText><title></title></link> or <link><linkText>FAQ for Microsoft Rights Management Sharing Application for Windows</linkText><title></title></link>:

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Automatic deployment for the Microsoft Rights Management sharing application</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Automatic deployment for the Microsoft Rights Management sharing application</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Azure RMS only: Configuring document tracking</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Technical overview for the Microsoft Rights Management sharing application</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Technical overview for the Microsoft Rights Management sharing application</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Levels of protection – native and generic</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Levels of protection – native and generic</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Supported file types and file name extensions</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Supported file types and file name extensions</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Changing the default protection level of files</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Changing the default protection level of files</linkText><title></title></link>

trans-unit.source: If you are new to the RMS sharing app, or looking for more information, see <link><linkText>How RMS protects all file types – by using the RMS sharing app</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you are new to the RMS sharing app, or looking for more information, see <link><linkText>How RMS protects all file types – by using the RMS sharing app</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: The RMS sharing application is best suited to work with Azure RMS, because this deployment configuration supports sending protected attachments to users in another organization, and options such as email notifications and document tracking with revocation.
trans-unit.target: The RMS sharing application is best suited to work with Azure RMS, because this deployment configuration supports sending protected attachments to users in another organization, and options such as email notifications and document tracking with revocation.

trans-unit.source: However, with some limitations, it also works with the on-premises version, AD RMS.
trans-unit.target: However, with some limitations, it also works with the on-premises version, AD RMS.

trans-unit.source: For a comprehensive comparison of features that are supported by Azure RMS and AD RMS, see <link><linkText>Comparing Azure Rights Management and AD RMS</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For a comprehensive comparison of features that are supported by Azure RMS and AD RMS, see <link><linkText>Comparing Azure Rights Management and AD RMS</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If you have AD RMS and want to migrate to Azure RMS, see <link><linkText>Migrating from AD RMS to Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you have AD RMS and want to migrate to Azure RMS, see <link><linkText>Migrating from AD RMS to Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Automatic deployment for the Microsoft Rights Management sharing application
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Automatic deployment for the Microsoft Rights Management sharing application

trans-unit.source: The Windows version of the RMS sharing application supports a scripted installation, which makes it suitable for enterprise deployments.
trans-unit.target: The Windows version of the RMS sharing application supports a scripted installation, which makes it suitable for enterprise deployments.

trans-unit.source: The only prerequisites for installations are that the computers run a minimum version of Windows 7 Service Pack 1, and that the Microsoft Framework, minimum version 4.0 is installed.
trans-unit.target: The only prerequisites for installations are that the computers run a minimum version of Windows 7 Service Pack 1, and that the Microsoft Framework, minimum version 4.0 is installed.

trans-unit.source: If you need to install the Microsoft .NET Framework 4.0, you can <link><linkText>download it for installation from the Microsoft Download Center</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: If you need to install the Microsoft .NET Framework 4.0, you can <link><linkText>download it for installation from the Microsoft Download Center</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To download the RMS sharing application for automatic deployment
trans-unit.target: To download the RMS sharing application for automatic deployment

trans-unit.source: Go to the Microsoft Rights Management sharing application for Windows page in the Microsoft Download Center, and click Download.
trans-unit.target: Go to the Microsoft Rights Management sharing application for Windows page in the Microsoft Download Center, and click Download.

trans-unit.source: Select and download the files that you need.
trans-unit.target: Select and download the files that you need.

trans-unit.source: There are two client installation packages: one for Windows 64-bit (Microsoft Rights Management sharing application x64.zip), and another for Windows 32-bit (Microsoft Rights Management sharing application x86.zip).
trans-unit.target: There are two client installation packages: one for Windows 64-bit (Microsoft Rights Management sharing application x64.zip), and another for Windows 32-bit (Microsoft Rights Management sharing application x86.zip).

trans-unit.source: Extract the files from the compressed installation packages, for example, by double-clicking them.
trans-unit.target: Extract the files from the compressed installation packages, for example, by double-clicking them.

trans-unit.source: Then copy the extracted files to a network location that client computers can access.
trans-unit.target: Then copy the extracted files to a network location that client computers can access.

trans-unit.source: The setup packages for the RMS sharing application supports different deployment scenarios and includes the following:
trans-unit.target: The setup packages for the RMS sharing application supports different deployment scenarios and includes the following:

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Deployment scenario
trans-unit.target: Deployment scenario

trans-unit.target: Microsoft Online Sign-In Assistant

trans-unit.source: Office 2016 or Office 2013 and Azure RMS or Active Directory RMS<html></html><html></html>Office 2010 and Azure RMS<html></html><html></html>Office 2010 and Active Directory RMS<html></html><html></html>RMS sharing application and Office add-in only
trans-unit.target: Office 2016 or Office 2013 and Azure RMS or Active Directory RMS<html></html><html></html>Office 2010 and Azure RMS<html></html><html></html>Office 2010 and Active Directory RMS<html></html><html></html>RMS sharing application and Office add-in only

trans-unit.source: Azure Active Directory Rights Management preparation tool
trans-unit.target: Azure Active Directory Rights Management preparation tool

trans-unit.source: Office 2010 and Azure RMS
trans-unit.target: Office 2010 and Azure RMS

trans-unit.source: Use the following procedures to identify the commands required to deploy the RMS sharing application for these deployment scenarios:
trans-unit.target: Use the following procedures to identify the commands required to deploy the RMS sharing application for these deployment scenarios:

trans-unit.source: Office 2016 or Office 2013 and Azure RMS or Active Directory RMS
trans-unit.target: Office 2016 or Office 2013 and Azure RMS or Active Directory RMS

trans-unit.source: Your users are running Office 2016 or Office 2013, your organization uses Azure RMS or Active Directory RMS, and users collaborate with other organizations who use Azure RMS or Active Directory RMS.
trans-unit.target: Your users are running Office 2016 or Office 2013, your organization uses Azure RMS or Active Directory RMS, and users collaborate with other organizations who use Azure RMS or Active Directory RMS.

trans-unit.source: Office 2010 and Azure RMS
trans-unit.target: Office 2010 and Azure RMS

trans-unit.source: Your users are running Office 2010, your organization uses Azure RMS, and users collaborate with other organizations who use Azure RMS or Active Directory RMS.
trans-unit.target: Your users are running Office 2010, your organization uses Azure RMS, and users collaborate with other organizations who use Azure RMS or Active Directory RMS.

trans-unit.source: Office 2010 and Active Directory RMS
trans-unit.target: Office 2010 and Active Directory RMS

trans-unit.source: Your users are running Office 2010, your organization uses AD RMS, and users collaborate with other organizations who use Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: Your users are running Office 2010, your organization uses AD RMS, and users collaborate with other organizations who use Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: RMS sharing application and Office add-in only
trans-unit.target: RMS sharing application and Office add-in only

trans-unit.source: Your users are running Office 2016, Office 2013, or Office 2010, your organization uses AD RMS, and users do not need to collaborate with other organizations who use Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: Your users are running Office 2016, Office 2013, or Office 2010, your organization uses AD RMS, and users do not need to collaborate with other organizations who use Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: This installation lets you install just the sharing application and Office add-in.
trans-unit.target: This installation lets you install just the sharing application and Office add-in.

trans-unit.source: In these scenarios, if your organization is running AD RMS, your users can receive protected content from other organizations who use Azure RMS, but your users cannot send protected content to users in an organization that uses Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: In these scenarios, if your organization is running AD RMS, your users can receive protected content from other organizations who use Azure RMS, but your users cannot send protected content to users in an organization that uses Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: However, if your organization is running Azure RMS, your users can send and receive protected content from other organizations.
trans-unit.target: However, if your organization is running Azure RMS, your users can send and receive protected content from other organizations.

trans-unit.source: To complete the installation for each procedure, the computer must restart.
trans-unit.target: To complete the installation for each procedure, the computer must restart.

trans-unit.source: You can initiate an automatic restart by using a command such as shutdown /i.
trans-unit.target: You can initiate an automatic restart by using a command such as shutdown /i.

trans-unit.source: To deploy the RMS sharing application for Office 2016 or Office 2013 and Azure RMS or Active Directory RMS
trans-unit.target: To deploy the RMS sharing application for Office 2016 or Office 2013 and Azure RMS or Active Directory RMS

trans-unit.source: On each computer on which you want to install the RMS sharing application and related components, run the following command with elevated privileges:
trans-unit.target: On each computer on which you want to install the RMS sharing application and related components, run the following command with elevated privileges:

trans-unit.source: To verify success, see the <link><linkText>Verifying installation success</linkText><title></title></link> section in this topic.
trans-unit.target: To verify success, see the <link><linkText>Verifying installation success</linkText><title></title></link> section in this topic.

trans-unit.source: To deploy the RMS sharing application for Office 2010 and Azure RMS
trans-unit.target: To deploy the RMS sharing application for Office 2010 and Azure RMS

trans-unit.source: You must be the global administrator for your Office 365 or Azure Active Directory tenant so that you can get your organization’s certification service URL by running the Azure Active Directory Rights Management preparation tool.
trans-unit.target: You must be the global administrator for your Office 365 or Azure Active Directory tenant so that you can get your organization’s certification service URL by running the Azure Active Directory Rights Management preparation tool.

trans-unit.source: You need run this tool only once, on a single computer.
trans-unit.target: You need run this tool only once, on a single computer.

trans-unit.source: You will use the certification service URL when you install the RMS sharing application on each computer:
trans-unit.target: You will use the certification service URL when you install the RMS sharing application on each computer:

trans-unit.source: Log in to a computer by using a local administrator account.
trans-unit.target: Log in to a computer by using a local administrator account.

trans-unit.source: On that computer, <link><linkText>download and install the Microsoft Online Sign In Assistant</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: On that computer, <link><linkText>download and install the Microsoft Online Sign In Assistant</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command to see displayed on the screen the certification service URL, which you can then copy and save for the next step:
trans-unit.target: Run the following command to see displayed on the screen the certification service URL, which you can then copy and save for the next step:

trans-unit.target: For Windows 8.1 and Windows 8, 64-bit:

trans-unit.target: For Windows 8.1 and Windows 8, 32-bit:

trans-unit.target: For Windows 7, 64-bit:

trans-unit.source: This command might prompt you to enter your credentials for Azure.
trans-unit.target: This command might prompt you to enter your credentials for Azure.

trans-unit.source: If the computer is not joined to a domain, you will be prompted.
trans-unit.target: If the computer is not joined to a domain, you will be prompted.

trans-unit.source: If the computer is joined to a domain, the tool might be able to use cached credentials.
trans-unit.target: If the computer is joined to a domain, the tool might be able to use cached credentials.

trans-unit.source: For example: \\server5\apps\rms\x64\setup_ipviewer.exe /norestart /quiet /msicl "MSIRESTARTMANAGERCONTROL=Disable" /log "C:\Log files\ipviewerinstall.log"
trans-unit.target: For example: \\server5\apps\rms\x64\setup_ipviewer.exe /norestart /quiet /msicl "MSIRESTARTMANAGERCONTROL=Disable" /log "C:\Log files\ipviewerinstall.log"

trans-unit.target: For 64-bit version of Office:

trans-unit.target: For 32-bit version of Office:

trans-unit.source: For example: \\server5\apps\rms\msiexec.exe /norestart /quiet MSIRESTARTMANAGERCONTROL=Disable /i "x64\Setup64.msi" /L*v "C:\Log files\rmsofficeinstall.log"
trans-unit.target: For example: \\server5\apps\rms\msiexec.exe /norestart /quiet MSIRESTARTMANAGERCONTROL=Disable /i "x64\Setup64.msi" /L*v "C:\Log files\rmsofficeinstall.log"

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Verifying installation success
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Verifying installation success

trans-unit.source: You can use the installation log files to verify a successful installation.
trans-unit.target: You can use the installation log files to verify a successful installation.

trans-unit.source: To verify installation success for the RMS sharing application for Office 2016 or Office 2013 and Azure RMS or Active Directory RMS
trans-unit.target: To verify installation success for the RMS sharing application for Office 2016 or Office 2013 and Azure RMS or Active Directory RMS

trans-unit.source: To verify success of the Setup.exe command, on each computer, search for the installation log file RMInstaller.log in the %temp%\RMS_installer_ folder, and then identify the exit code.
trans-unit.target: To verify success of the Setup.exe command, on each computer, search for the installation log file RMInstaller.log in the %temp%\RMS_installer_ folder, and then identify the exit code.

trans-unit.source: A successful installation has an exit code of 0 and any other number indicates a failed installation.
trans-unit.target: A successful installation has an exit code of 0 and any other number indicates a failed installation.

trans-unit.source: Example log file name: C:\temp\RMS_Installer_9352fc91-1982-43bf-958a-2ef1fe9c2ed0\RMInstaller.log
trans-unit.target: Example log file name: C:\temp\RMS_Installer_9352fc91-1982-43bf-958a-2ef1fe9c2ed0\RMInstaller.log

trans-unit.source: To verify installation success for the RMS sharing application for Office 2010 and Azure RMS
trans-unit.target: To verify installation success for the RMS sharing application for Office 2010 and Azure RMS

trans-unit.source: To verify success of the Setup.exe command, on each computer, search for the installation log file RMInstaller.log in the %temp%\RMS_installer_ folder, and then identify the exit code.
trans-unit.target: To verify success of the Setup.exe command, on each computer, search for the installation log file RMInstaller.log in the %temp%\RMS_installer_ folder, and then identify the exit code.

trans-unit.source: A successful installation has an exit code of 0 and any other number indicates a failed installation.
trans-unit.target: A successful installation has an exit code of 0 and any other number indicates a failed installation.

trans-unit.source: Example log file name: C:\temp\RMS_Installer_9352fc91-1982-43bf-958a-2ef1fe9c2ed0
trans-unit.target: Example log file name: C:\temp\RMS_Installer_9352fc91-1982-43bf-958a-2ef1fe9c2ed0

trans-unit.source: To verify success for the RMSSetup.exe command, the user should have the following files created in their %localappdata%\microsoft\drm folder:
trans-unit.target: To verify success for the RMSSetup.exe command, the user should have the following files created in their %localappdata%\microsoft\drm folder:

trans-unit.source: CERT-Machine-2048.drm
trans-unit.target: CERT-Machine-2048.drm

trans-unit.source: CERT-Machine.drm
trans-unit.target: CERT-Machine.drm

trans-unit.source: CLC-*.drm
trans-unit.target: CLC-*.drm

trans-unit.source: GIC-*.drm
trans-unit.target: GIC-*.drm

trans-unit.source: Example of a CLC-*.drm file:
trans-unit.target: Example of a CLC-*.drm file:

trans-unit.source: CLC-alice@isvtenant999.onmicrosoft.com-{1b9cfccf;k5b11;k4a10;kac15;k29b2b6980f4c}.drm
trans-unit.target: CLC-alice@isvtenant999.onmicrosoft.com-{1b9cfccf;k5b11;k4a10;kac15;k29b2b6980f4c}.drm

trans-unit.source: To verify installation success for the RMS sharing application for Office 2010 and Active Directory RMS
trans-unit.target: To verify installation success for the RMS sharing application for Office 2010 and Active Directory RMS

trans-unit.source: To verify success of the Setup.exe command, on each computer, search for the installation log file in the %temp%\RMS_installer_ folder, and identify the exit code.
trans-unit.target: To verify success of the Setup.exe command, on each computer, search for the installation log file in the %temp%\RMS_installer_ folder, and identify the exit code.

trans-unit.source: A successful installation has an exit code of 0 and any other number indicates a failed installation.
trans-unit.target: A successful installation has an exit code of 0 and any other number indicates a failed installation.

trans-unit.source: Example log file name: C:\temp\RMS_Installer_9352fc91-1982-43bf-958a-2ef1fe9c2ed0
trans-unit.target: Example log file name: C:\temp\RMS_Installer_9352fc91-1982-43bf-958a-2ef1fe9c2ed0

trans-unit.source: To verify success of the aadrmprep.exe command, on each computer, search for the following text in the installation log file: aadrmprep.exe exited with status SUCCESS
trans-unit.target: To verify success of the aadrmprep.exe command, on each computer, search for the following text in the installation log file: aadrmprep.exe exited with status SUCCESS

trans-unit.source: Sometimes, this installation can run twice; the first occurrence fails and the second is successful.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes, this installation can run twice; the first occurrence fails and the second is successful.

trans-unit.source: If you want to manually check the registry changes that this tool makes, they are as follows:
trans-unit.target: If you want to manually check the registry changes that this tool makes, they are as follows:

trans-unit.source: [HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\MSDRM\Federation]
trans-unit.target: [HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\MSDRM\Federation]

trans-unit.source: "FederationHomeRealm"="urn:HostedRmsOnlineService:Certification"
trans-unit.target: "FederationHomeRealm"="urn:HostedRmsOnlineService:Certification"

trans-unit.source: [HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Wow6432Node\Microsoft\MSDRM\Federation]
trans-unit.target: [HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Wow6432Node\Microsoft\MSDRM\Federation]

trans-unit.source: "FederationHomeRealm"="urn:HostedRmsOnlineService:Certification"
trans-unit.target: "FederationHomeRealm"="urn:HostedRmsOnlineService:Certification"

trans-unit.source: [HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Wow6432Node\Microsoft\MSDRM\ServiceLocation\Activation]
trans-unit.target: [HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Wow6432Node\Microsoft\MSDRM\ServiceLocation\Activation]

trans-unit.source: @="<certification url>"
trans-unit.target: @="<certification url>"

trans-unit.source: [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\14.0\Common\DRM]
trans-unit.target: [HKEY_CURRENT_USER\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Office\14.0\Common\DRM]

trans-unit.source: DefaultUser="<default_user>"
trans-unit.target: DefaultUser="<default_user>"

trans-unit.source: To verify installation success for the RMS sharing application and Office add-in only
trans-unit.target: To verify installation success for the RMS sharing application and Office add-in only

trans-unit.source: To verify success of the Setup_ipviewer.exe command, search for the following text in the installation log file: Installation success or error status: 0
trans-unit.target: To verify success of the Setup_ipviewer.exe command, search for the following text in the installation log file: Installation success or error status: 0

trans-unit.source: Example lines from a successful installation:
trans-unit.target: Example lines from a successful installation:

trans-unit.source: MSI (s) (F0:B8) [14:19:57:854]: Product: Active Directory Rights Management Services Client 2.1 -- Installation completed successfully.
trans-unit.target: MSI (s) (F0:B8) [14:19:57:854]: Product: Active Directory Rights Management Services Client 2.1 -- Installation completed successfully.

trans-unit.source: **MSI (s) (F0:B8) [14:19:57:854]: Windows Installer installed the product.
trans-unit.target: **MSI (s) (F0:B8) [14:19:57:854]: Windows Installer installed the product.

trans-unit.source: Product Name: Active Directory Rights Management Services Client 2.1.
trans-unit.target: Product Name: Active Directory Rights Management Services Client 2.1.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Uninstall commands
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Uninstall commands

trans-unit.source: Not all of the installation commands that are required for these deployments support an uninstallation command.
trans-unit.target: Not all of the installation commands that are required for these deployments support an uninstallation command.

trans-unit.source: You can uninstall the AD RMS client and the sharing application, and you can uninstall the Office add-in.
trans-unit.target: You can uninstall the AD RMS client and the sharing application, and you can uninstall the Office add-in.

trans-unit.source: Use the following commands to uninstall these elements.
trans-unit.target: Use the following commands to uninstall these elements.

trans-unit.source: To uninstall the AD RMS Client and the RMS sharing application
trans-unit.target: To uninstall the AD RMS Client and the RMS sharing application

trans-unit.source: Use the following commands:
trans-unit.target: Use the following commands:

trans-unit.source: For 64-bit Windows:
trans-unit.target: For 64-bit Windows:

trans-unit.source: For 32-bit Windows:
trans-unit.target: For 32-bit Windows:

trans-unit.source: To uninstall the Office add-in
trans-unit.target: To uninstall the Office add-in

trans-unit.source: Use the following commands:
trans-unit.target: Use the following commands:

trans-unit.source: For 64-bit version of Office:
trans-unit.target: For 64-bit version of Office:

trans-unit.source: For 32-bit version of Office:
trans-unit.target: For 32-bit version of Office:

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Suppressing automatic updates
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Suppressing automatic updates

trans-unit.source: By default, users are notified if there is a later version of the RMS sharing application, and prompted to download it.
trans-unit.target: By default, users are notified if there is a later version of the RMS sharing application, and prompted to download it.

trans-unit.source: You can suppress this notification by making the following registry edit:
trans-unit.target: You can suppress this notification by making the following registry edit:

trans-unit.source: Navigate to HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\MSIPC and if not already present, create a new key named RmsSharingApp.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\MSIPC and if not already present, create a new key named RmsSharingApp.

trans-unit.source: Select RmsSharingApp, create a new DWORD Value of AllowUpdatePrompt, and set the value to 0.
trans-unit.target: Select RmsSharingApp, create a new DWORD Value of AllowUpdatePrompt, and set the value to 0.

trans-unit.source: Because the RMS sharing application is not supported by WSUS, you can use the following technique to test any new versions of the RMS sharing application before deploying it to all users:
trans-unit.target: Because the RMS sharing application is not supported by WSUS, you can use the following technique to test any new versions of the RMS sharing application before deploying it to all users:

trans-unit.source: On all users’ computers, run a script to suppress automatic updates.
trans-unit.target: On all users’ computers, run a script to suppress automatic updates.

trans-unit.source: On the computers that administrators use to test new versions, do not run this script.
trans-unit.target: On the computers that administrators use to test new versions, do not run this script.

trans-unit.source: When a new version is available, administrators download it and test it.
trans-unit.target: When a new version is available, administrators download it and test it.

trans-unit.source: When testing is complete and any issues resolved, deploy the latest version to all users by using the automatic deployment instructions in this guide.
trans-unit.target: When testing is complete and any issues resolved, deploy the latest version to all users by using the automatic deployment instructions in this guide.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Azure RMS only: Configuring document tracking
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Azure RMS only: Configuring document tracking

trans-unit.source: If you have a <link><linkText>subscription that supports document tracking</linkText><title></title></link>, the document tracking site is enabled by default for all users in your organization.
trans-unit.target: If you have a <link><linkText>subscription that supports document tracking</linkText><title></title></link>, the document tracking site is enabled by default for all users in your organization.

trans-unit.source: Document tracking shows information such as email addresses of the people who attempted to access protected documents that users shared, when these people tried to access them, and their location.
trans-unit.target: Document tracking shows information such as email addresses of the people who attempted to access protected documents that users shared, when these people tried to access them, and their location.

trans-unit.source: If displaying this information is prohibited in your organization because of privacy requirements, you can disable access to the document tracking site by using the <link><linkText>Disable-AadrmDocumentTrackingFeature</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: If displaying this information is prohibited in your organization because of privacy requirements, you can disable access to the document tracking site by using the <link><linkText>Disable-AadrmDocumentTrackingFeature</linkText><title></title></link> cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: You can re-enable access to the site at any time, by using the <link><linkText>Enable-AadrmDocumentTrackingFeature</linkText><title></title></link>, and you can check whether access is currently enabled or disabled by using <link><linkText>Get-AadrmDocumentTrackingFeature</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: You can re-enable access to the site at any time, by using the <link><linkText>Enable-AadrmDocumentTrackingFeature</linkText><title></title></link>, and you can check whether access is currently enabled or disabled by using <link><linkText>Get-AadrmDocumentTrackingFeature</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: To run these cmdlets, you must have at least version 2.3.0.0 of the Azure RMS module for Windows PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: To run these cmdlets, you must have at least version 2.3.0.0 of the Azure RMS module for Windows PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: For installation instructions, see <link><linkText>Installing Windows PowerShell for Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For installation instructions, see <link><linkText>Installing Windows PowerShell for Azure Rights Management</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: If you have previously downloaded and installed the module, check the version number by running: (Get-Module aadrm –ListAvailable).Version
trans-unit.target: If you have previously downloaded and installed the module, check the version number by running: (Get-Module aadrm –ListAvailable).Version

trans-unit.source: The following URLs are used for document tracking and must be allowed (for example, add them to your Trusted Sites if you're using Internet Explorer with Enhanced Security):
trans-unit.target: The following URLs are used for document tracking and must be allowed (for example, add them to your Trusted Sites if you're using Internet Explorer with Enhanced Security):

trans-unit.source: https://*.azurerms.com
trans-unit.target: https://*.azurerms.com

trans-unit.source: https://ecn.dev.virtualearth.net
trans-unit.target: https://ecn.dev.virtualearth.net

trans-unit.source: This URL is for Bing maps.
trans-unit.target: This URL is for Bing maps.

trans-unit.source: https://*.microsoftonline.com
trans-unit.target: https://*.microsoftonline.com

trans-unit.source: https://*.microsoftonline-p.com
trans-unit.target: https://*.microsoftonline-p.com

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>AD RMS only: Support for multiple email domains within your organization
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>AD RMS only: Support for multiple email domains within your organization

trans-unit.source: If you use AD RMS and users in your organization have multiple email domains, perhaps as a result of a merger or acquisition, you must make the following registry edit:
trans-unit.target: If you use AD RMS and users in your organization have multiple email domains, perhaps as a result of a merger or acquisition, you must make the following registry edit:

trans-unit.source: Navigate to HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\MSIPC and if not already present, create a new key named RmsSharingApp.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\MSIPC and if not already present, create a new key named RmsSharingApp.

trans-unit.source: Select RmsSharingApp, create a new Multi-String Value named FederatedDomains, and then add the domains and all the subdomains that your organization uses.
trans-unit.target: Select RmsSharingApp, create a new Multi-String Value named FederatedDomains, and then add the domains and all the subdomains that your organization uses.

trans-unit.source: Wildcards are not supported.
trans-unit.target: Wildcards are not supported.

trans-unit.source: For example: The company Coho Vineyard & Winery has a standard email domain of cohovineyardandwinery.com, but as a result of mergers, they also use the email domains cohowinery.com, eastcoast.cohowinery.com, and cohovineyard.
trans-unit.target: For example: The company Coho Vineyard & Winery has a standard email domain of cohovineyardandwinery.com, but as a result of mergers, they also use the email domains cohowinery.com, eastcoast.cohowinery.com, and cohovineyard.

trans-unit.source: For the FederatedDomains value data, the administrator enters: cohowinery.com; eastcoast.cohowinery.com; cohovineyard
trans-unit.target: For the FederatedDomains value data, the administrator enters: cohowinery.com; eastcoast.cohowinery.com; cohovineyard

trans-unit.source: If you do not make this registry change, users might not be able to consume content that has been protected by other users in their organization.
trans-unit.target: If you do not make this registry change, users might not be able to consume content that has been protected by other users in their organization.

trans-unit.source: This registry edit is not needed if you use Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: This registry edit is not needed if you use Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Technical overview for the Microsoft Rights Management sharing application
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Technical overview for the Microsoft Rights Management sharing application

trans-unit.source: The Microsoft Rights Management sharing application is an optional downloadable application for Microsoft Windows and other platforms that provides the following:
trans-unit.target: The Microsoft Rights Management sharing application is an optional downloadable application for Microsoft Windows and other platforms that provides the following:

trans-unit.source: Protection of a single file or bulk protection of multiple files as well as all files within a selected folder.
trans-unit.target: Protection of a single file or bulk protection of multiple files as well as all files within a selected folder.

trans-unit.source: Full support for protection of any type of file and a built-in viewer for commonly used text and image file types.
trans-unit.target: Full support for protection of any type of file and a built-in viewer for commonly used text and image file types.

trans-unit.source: Generic protection for files that do not support RMS protection.
trans-unit.target: Generic protection for files that do not support RMS protection.

trans-unit.source: Full interoperability with files protected using Office Information Rights Management (IRM).
trans-unit.target: Full interoperability with files protected using Office Information Rights Management (IRM).

trans-unit.source: Full interoperability with PDF files protected using SharePoint, FCI, and supported PDF authoring tools.
trans-unit.target: Full interoperability with PDF files protected using SharePoint, FCI, and supported PDF authoring tools.

trans-unit.source: The Microsoft Rights Management sharing application uses the new <link><linkText>AD RMS Client 2.1 runtime</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: The Microsoft Rights Management sharing application uses the new <link><linkText>AD RMS Client 2.1 runtime</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: By using the functionality of AD RMS 2.1, the Microsoft Rights Management sharing application provides end users a simple protection and consumption experience.
trans-unit.target: By using the functionality of AD RMS 2.1, the Microsoft Rights Management sharing application provides end users a simple protection and consumption experience.

trans-unit.source: With the October 2013 release of RMS, you can natively protect documents by using Office 2010 and send them to people in another company, who can then consume them by using Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: With the October 2013 release of RMS, you can natively protect documents by using Office 2010 and send them to people in another company, who can then consume them by using Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: In addition, with this release, if you use AD RMS in Cryptographic Mode 2, you can use RMS for individuals and consume content from people in another company that uses Azure RMS.
trans-unit.target: In addition, with this release, if you use AD RMS in Cryptographic Mode 2, you can use RMS for individuals and consume content from people in another company that uses Azure RMS.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Cryptographic Mode 2, see <link><linkText>AD RMS Cryptographic Modes</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Cryptographic Mode 2, see <link><linkText>AD RMS Cryptographic Modes</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Levels of protection – native and generic
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Levels of protection – native and generic

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Rights Management sharing application supports protection at two different levels, as described in the following table.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Rights Management sharing application supports protection at two different levels, as described in the following table.

trans-unit.source: Type of protection
trans-unit.target: Type of protection

trans-unit.source: Native
trans-unit.target: Native

trans-unit.source: Generic
trans-unit.target: Generic

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: For text, image, Microsoft Office (Word, Excel, PowerPoint) files, .pdf files, and other application file types that support AD RMS, native protection provides a strong level of protection that includes both encryption and enforcement of rights (permissions).
trans-unit.target: For text, image, Microsoft Office (Word, Excel, PowerPoint) files, .pdf files, and other application file types that support AD RMS, native protection provides a strong level of protection that includes both encryption and enforcement of rights (permissions).

trans-unit.source: For all other applications and file types, generic protection provides a level of protection that includes both file encapsulation using the .pfile file type and authentication to verify if a user is authorized to open the file.
trans-unit.target: For all other applications and file types, generic protection provides a level of protection that includes both file encapsulation using the .pfile file type and authentication to verify if a user is authorized to open the file.

trans-unit.source: Protection
trans-unit.target: Protection

trans-unit.source: Files are fully encrypted and protection is enforced in the following ways:<html></html><html></html>Before protected content is rendered, successful authentication must occur for those who receive the file through email or are given access to it through file or share permissions.<html></html><html></html>Additionally, usage rights and policy set by the content owner when files are protected are fully enforced when the content is rendered in either IP Viewer (for protected text and image files) or the associated application (for all other supported file types).
trans-unit.target: Files are fully encrypted and protection is enforced in the following ways:<html></html><html></html>Before protected content is rendered, successful authentication must occur for those who receive the file through email or are given access to it through file or share permissions.<html></html><html></html>Additionally, usage rights and policy set by the content owner when files are protected are fully enforced when the content is rendered in either IP Viewer (for protected text and image files) or the associated application (for all other supported file types).

trans-unit.source: File protection is enforced in the following ways:<html></html><html></html>Before protected content is rendered, successful authentication must occur for those who are authorized to open the file and given access to it.
trans-unit.target: File protection is enforced in the following ways:<html></html><html></html>Before protected content is rendered, successful authentication must occur for those who are authorized to open the file and given access to it.

trans-unit.source: If authorization fails, the file does not open.<html></html><html></html>Usage rights and policy set by the content owner are displayed to inform authorized users of the intended usage policy.<html></html><html></html>Audit logging of authorized users opening and accessing files occurs, however, no usage rights are enforced by non-supporting applications.
trans-unit.target: If authorization fails, the file does not open.<html></html><html></html>Usage rights and policy set by the content owner are displayed to inform authorized users of the intended usage policy.<html></html><html></html>Audit logging of authorized users opening and accessing files occurs, however, no usage rights are enforced by non-supporting applications.

trans-unit.source: Default for file types
trans-unit.target: Default for file types

trans-unit.source: This is the default level of protection for the following file types:<html></html><html></html>Text and image files<html></html><html></html>Microsoft Office (Word, Excel, PowerPoint) files<html></html><html></html>Portable document format (.pdf)<html></html><html></html>For more information, see the following section, <link><linkText>Supported file types and file name extensions</linkText><title></title></link>.
trans-unit.target: This is the default level of protection for the following file types:<html></html><html></html>Text and image files<html></html><html></html>Microsoft Office (Word, Excel, PowerPoint) files<html></html><html></html>Portable document format (.pdf)<html></html><html></html>For more information, see the following section, <link><linkText>Supported file types and file name extensions</linkText><title></title></link>.

trans-unit.source: This is the default protection for all other file types (such as .vsdx, .rtf, and so on) that are not supported by full protection.
trans-unit.target: This is the default protection for all other file types (such as .vsdx, .rtf, and so on) that are not supported by full protection.

trans-unit.source: You can change the default protection level that the RMS sharing application applies.
trans-unit.target: You can change the default protection level that the RMS sharing application applies.

trans-unit.source: You can change the default level of native to generic, from generic to native, and even prevent the RMS sharing application from applying protection.
trans-unit.target: You can change the default level of native to generic, from generic to native, and even prevent the RMS sharing application from applying protection.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the <link><linkText>Changing the default protection level of files</linkText><title></title></link> section in this topic.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the <link><linkText>Changing the default protection level of files</linkText><title></title></link> section in this topic.

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Supported file types and file name extensions
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Supported file types and file name extensions

trans-unit.source: The following table lists file types that are natively supported by Microsoft Rights Management sharing application.
trans-unit.target: The following table lists file types that are natively supported by Microsoft Rights Management sharing application.

trans-unit.source: For these file types, the original file name extension is changed when native protected is applied, and these files become read-only.
trans-unit.target: For these file types, the original file name extension is changed when native protected is applied, and these files become read-only.

trans-unit.source: In addition, when the RMS sharing application natively protects a Word, Excel, or PowerPoint file that users protect by sharing, this action automatically creates a second file that is a copy of the original with the same file name but with a .ppdf file name extension ¹.
trans-unit.target: In addition, when the RMS sharing application natively protects a Word, Excel, or PowerPoint file that users protect by sharing, this action automatically creates a second file that is a copy of the original with the same file name but with a .ppdf file name extension ¹.

trans-unit.source: This version of the file ensures that recipients who install the RMS sharing application can always open the file that has native protection applied.
trans-unit.target: This version of the file ensures that recipients who install the RMS sharing application can always open the file that has native protection applied.

trans-unit.source: For files that are generically protected, the original file name extension is always changed to .pfile.
trans-unit.target: For files that are generically protected, the original file name extension is always changed to .pfile.

trans-unit.source: If you have firewalls, web proxies, or security software that inspect and take action according to file name extensions, you might need to reconfigure these to support these new file name extensions.
trans-unit.target: If you have firewalls, web proxies, or security software that inspect and take action according to file name extensions, you might need to reconfigure these to support these new file name extensions.

trans-unit.source: Original file name extension
trans-unit.target: Original file name extension

trans-unit.source: RMS-protected file name extension
trans-unit.target: RMS-protected file name extension

trans-unit.target: .pjpe

trans-unit.target: .jfif

trans-unit.target: ¹ PDF Rendering Powered by Foxit.

trans-unit.target: Copyright © 2003–2014 by Foxit Corporation.

trans-unit.source: The following table lists the file types that the Microsoft Rights Management sharing application natively supports in Microsoft Office 2016, Office 2013, and Office 2010.
trans-unit.target: The following table lists the file types that the Microsoft Rights Management sharing application natively supports in Microsoft Office 2016, Office 2013, and Office 2010.

trans-unit.source: For these files, the file name extension remains the same after the file is protected by RMS.
trans-unit.target: For these files, the file name extension remains the same after the file is protected by RMS.

trans-unit.source: File types supported by Office
trans-unit.target: File types supported by Office

trans-unit.target: File types supported by Office

trans-unit.source: <html></html><html></html>Changing the default protection level of files
trans-unit.target: <html></html><html></html>Changing the default protection level of files

trans-unit.source: You can change how the RMS sharing application protects files by editing the registry.
trans-unit.target: You can change how the RMS sharing application protects files by editing the registry.

trans-unit.source: For example, you can force files that support native protection to be generically protected by the RMS sharing application.
trans-unit.target: For example, you can force files that support native protection to be generically protected by the RMS sharing application.

trans-unit.source: Reasons for why you might want to do this:
trans-unit.target: Reasons for why you might want to do this:

trans-unit.source: To ensure that all users can open the file from their mobile devices.
trans-unit.target: To ensure that all users can open the file from their mobile devices.

trans-unit.source: To ensure that all users can open the file if they don’t have an application that supports native protection.
trans-unit.target: To ensure that all users can open the file if they don’t have an application that supports native protection.

trans-unit.source: To accommodate security systems that take action on files by their file name extension and can be reconfigured to accommodate the .pfile file name extension but cannot be reconfigured to accommodate multiple file name extensions for native protection.
trans-unit.target: To accommodate security systems that take action on files by their file name extension and can be reconfigured to accommodate the .pfile file name extension but cannot be reconfigured to accommodate multiple file name extensions for native protection.

trans-unit.source: Similarly, you can force the RMS sharing application to apply native protection to files that by default, would have generic protection applied.
trans-unit.target: Similarly, you can force the RMS sharing application to apply native protection to files that by default, would have generic protection applied.

trans-unit.source: This might be appropriate if you have an application that supports the RMS APIs – for example, a line-of-business application written by your internal developers or an application purchased from an independent software vendor (ISV).
trans-unit.target: This might be appropriate if you have an application that supports the RMS APIs – for example, a line-of-business application written by your internal developers or an application purchased from an independent software vendor (ISV).

trans-unit.source: You can also force the RMS sharing application to block the protection of files (not apply native protection or generic protection).
trans-unit.target: You can also force the RMS sharing application to block the protection of files (not apply native protection or generic protection).

trans-unit.source: For example, this might be required if you have an automated application or service that must be able to open a specific file to process its contents.
trans-unit.target: For example, this might be required if you have an automated application or service that must be able to open a specific file to process its contents.

trans-unit.source: When you block protection for a file type, users cannot use the RMS sharing application to protect a file that has that file type.
trans-unit.target: When you block protection for a file type, users cannot use the RMS sharing application to protect a file that has that file type.

trans-unit.source: When they try, they see a message that the administrator has prevented protection and they must cancel their action to protect the file.
trans-unit.target: When they try, they see a message that the administrator has prevented protection and they must cancel their action to protect the file.

trans-unit.source: To configure the RMS sharing application to apply generic protection to all files that by default, would have native protection applied, make the following registry edits:
trans-unit.target: To configure the RMS sharing application to apply generic protection to all files that by default, would have native protection applied, make the following registry edits:

trans-unit.source: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\MSIPC\RMSSharingApp\FileProtection: Create a new key named *.
trans-unit.target: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\MSIPC\RMSSharingApp\FileProtection: Create a new key named *.

trans-unit.source: This setting denotes files with any file name extension.
trans-unit.target: This setting denotes files with any file name extension.

trans-unit.source: In the newly added key of HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\MSIPC\RMSSharingApp\FileProtection\*, create a new string value (REG_SZ) named Encryption that has the data value of Pfile.
trans-unit.target: In the newly added key of HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\MSIPC\RMSSharingApp\FileProtection\*, create a new string value (REG_SZ) named Encryption that has the data value of Pfile.

trans-unit.source: This setting results in the RMS sharing application applying generic protection.
trans-unit.target: This setting results in the RMS sharing application applying generic protection.

trans-unit.source: These two settings result in the RMS sharing application applying generic protection to all files that have a file name extension.
trans-unit.target: These two settings result in the RMS sharing application applying generic protection to all files that have a file name extension.

trans-unit.source: If this is your goal, no further configuration is required.
trans-unit.target: If this is your goal, no further configuration is required.

trans-unit.source: However, you can define exceptions for specific file types, so that they are still natively protected.
trans-unit.target: However, you can define exceptions for specific file types, so that they are still natively protected.

trans-unit.source: To do this, you must make three additional registry edits for each file type:
trans-unit.target: To do this, you must make three additional registry edits for each file type:

trans-unit.source: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\MSIPC\RMSSharingApp\FileProtection: Add a new key that has the name of the file name extension (without the preceding period).
trans-unit.target: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\MSIPC\RMSSharingApp\FileProtection: Add a new key that has the name of the file name extension (without the preceding period).

trans-unit.source: For example, for files that have a .docx file name extension, create a key named DOCX.
trans-unit.target: For example, for files that have a .docx file name extension, create a key named DOCX.

trans-unit.source: In the newly added file type key (for example, HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\MSIPC\RMSSharingApp\FileProtection\DOCX), create a new DWORD Value named AllowPFILEEncryption that has a value of 0.
trans-unit.target: In the newly added file type key (for example, HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\MSIPC\RMSSharingApp\FileProtection\DOCX), create a new DWORD Value named AllowPFILEEncryption that has a value of 0.

trans-unit.source: In the newly added file type key (for example, HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\MSIPC\RMSSharingApp\FileProtection\DOCX), create a new String Value named Encryption that has a value of Native.
trans-unit.target: In the newly added file type key (for example, HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Microsoft\MSIPC\RMSSharingApp\FileProtection\DOCX), create a new String Value named Encryption that has a value of Native.

trans-unit.source: As a result of these settings, all files are generically protected except files that have a .docx file name extension, which are natively protected by the RMS sharing application.
trans-unit.target: As a result of these settings, all files are generically protected except files that have a .docx file name extension, which are natively protected by the RMS sharing application.

trans-unit.source: Repeat these three steps for other file types that you want to define as exceptions because they support native protection and you do not want them to be generically protected by the RMS sharing application.
trans-unit.target: Repeat these three steps for other file types that you want to define as exceptions because they support native protection and you do not want them to be generically protected by the RMS sharing application.

trans-unit.source: You can make similar registry edits for other scenarios by changing the value of the Encryption string that supports the following values:
trans-unit.target: You can make similar registry edits for other scenarios by changing the value of the Encryption string that supports the following values:

trans-unit.source: Pfile: Generic protection
trans-unit.target: Pfile: Generic protection

trans-unit.source: Native: Native protection
trans-unit.target: Native: Native protection

trans-unit.source: Off: Block protection
trans-unit.target: Off: Block protection

trans-unit.source: See Also
trans-unit.target: See Also

trans-unit.source: <link><linkText>Rights Management sharing application user guide</linkText><title></title></link>
trans-unit.target: <link><linkText>Rights Management sharing application user guide</linkText><title></title></link>
